results.title: Aboriginal art: conserving, exhibiting, interpreting
results.creator_credit: Christoph Willing, David Roberts, Peter Lipscombe and University of Sydney Television Service
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Talking about Aboriginal art”.
In recent decades Aboriginal art has increasingly been destined for art museums and major private collections. It has not been totally subsumed into the Western art dealer and museum system, but has made curators and art historians ask some profound questions about their practices and policies of collecting and exhibiting art. One concern is the involvement of non- Aboriginal curators and art advisers, with many believing they occupy positions which would be more appropriately held by Aboriginal people. Curators Djon Mundine, Wally Caruana and Peter Sutton discuss gallery collecting policies, major exhibitions and key issues in the criticism of contemporary Aboriginal art.

results.title: Abnormal behavior: a mental hospital (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Tom Lazarus, Neil Reichline and CRM Productions
results.brief_description: A series of doctor-patient interviews acquaint the viewer with the symptomatology of various types of schizophrenic disturbances. In an unusual sequence, a patient with paranoid tendencies is shown undergoing electro-convulsive therapy. The director of the hospital tells of the hospital’s goals in this and other forms of treatment.

results.title: Ablutions
results.brief_description: Ablutions is an interactive journey where the user controls the fate of a character in a world that consumes technology. Through exploring the narrative the user partakes in the experience of cleansing the self from everyday technology and its commodities; questioning the nature of our identity. By doing this, freedom is redefined. Once cleansed, the character recovers the lost items, discovering their meaning and importance.

results.title: Ablett: one special season
results.creator_credit: Stephen Phillips, Dean Shiel and Australian Football Video
results.brief_description: In one special season Gary Ablett redefined the way Australian Rules football’s rich history will judge him. Having set standards rarely matched by other players since his career began, Ablett’s 1993 was quite extraordinary - even for a man prone to producing the extraordinary. We follow Ablett’s path through the season, hear him speak on his performance and his place in the Geelong team and travel to Nauru with him as he umpires the local Grand Final. This is a fine tribute to one of the legends of the game.

results.title: Abilene Paradox (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Peter Jordon, Janice M Reynolds and CRM Productions
results.brief_description: Deals with the management of agreement in organisations. Illustrates that mismanaged agreement is as dangerous to organisational effectiveness as excessive conflict because it can lead to inappropriate goals.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Peter Jordon, Janice M Reynolds and CRM Productions

results.title: Abigail (Emma Stone) costume from The Favourite
results.credit_line:
Cotton, linen, nylon, canvas, pearl, ribbon, bamboo and rag paper, synthetic polyester fibre

Courtesy of the Walt Disney Company
results.material_description: Cotton, linen, nylon, canvas, pearl, ribbon, bamboo and rag paper, synethtic polyester fiber
results.brief_description: When we first meet Abigail Masham (Emma Stone) in The Favourite (2018), she’s covered in mud after being kicked from a carriage. It’s a humble start, but as she climbs Queen Anne’s (Olivia Colman) court her costumes become increasingly lavish.

constellations_primary.name: Making films in black and white
constellations_primary.description: Oscar-winner Sandy Powell crafted Abigail's (Emma Stone) costume in The Favourite to represent her ascension in the royal household of Queen Anne by utilising black and white.

results.description: Abigail Masham (Emma Stone) is down on her luck. Her wealthy family has made bad investments, and when we first meet her in The Favourite (2018), she’s pleading (politely) for a job in Queen Anne’s palace. It’s not the most flattering start – she’s covered in mud after being kicked from a carriage – but she’s soon promoted to lady-in-waiting and trades her grubby attire for a sleek black dress. As she climbs up the court, more and more white is added to her outfit, demonstrated by the trim on this costume. By the end of the film she’s draped in a completely over-the-top white dress that establishes her influence and shows how far she’s come.
